awd_titl_txt: GOALI: Advancing Thermal Field-Flow Fractionation for Complex Polymers and Colloids
awd_abstract_narration:
This project is supported by the Chemical Measurement and Imaging program of the Chemistry Division. Professor Kim Williams of the Colorado School of Mines (CSM) is developing thermal field-flow fractionation (ThFFF) as a versatile platform for separating and characterizing complex polymers and colloids. Thermal diffusion in liquids presents a novel way of separating and analyzing mixtures of plastics and other very large molecules.  This project uses the NSF Grant Opportunities for Academic Liaison with Industry (GOALI) mechanism to for a collaboration between Dr. Williams' lab and Dow Chemical Company. The academic/industrial collaboration serves as a model for combining expertise in separation science, that may lead to insights about product performance. An outreach program developed by Professor Williams brings science and discovery to students with learning disabilities (dyslexia) and introduces future teachers in the STEM Teacher Education program at CSM. Students relate well to the textural and visual nature of these polymer and colloid activities  and thus, outreach activities are carried out at the Rocky Mountain Camp for Dyslexic Youths. These low cost and safe hands-on experiments introduce to students in the STEM Teacher Education program at the Colorado School of Mines.  The broader impacts of this work include technical benefits through better designed (more environmentally friendly) products, and educational benefits for the students and scientists who are trained in an industrial and academic setting.

Ultrahigh molecular weight or ultralarge polymers and colloid surface characterizations are analytical challenges. Reliable methods for determining molecular weight distributions do not currently exist for these materials. The objectives for this work are to develop and test thermal field-flow fractionation (ThFFF) for ultralarge (>100 nm or >103 kDa) polymers.  The researchers determine experimental approaches that provide additional control of thermal diffusion of colloids and demonstrate their use for surface composition/charge separations and analyses.  They also identify a working particle thermophoresis theory. An outreach program developed by Professor Williams brings science and discovery to students with learning disabilities (dyslexia) and introduces future teachers in the STEM Teacher Education program at CSM. The broader impacts of this work include potential societal benefits through better designed (more environmentally friendly) products, students and scientists who are trained in an industrial and academic setting, and more experienced future STEM teachers. Innovative analytical methods that result from this work may impact science and technologies associated with polymers and colloids (natural, biological, and synthetic). The close collaboration between CSM and Dow scientists improves research impact and develops the next generation work force through students' exposure to industry.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Polymers and colloids are among the key components in a multitude of consumer products that range from plastic containers to drug delivery carriers.  Variations in molar mass/size, chemical composition, degree of branching, charge and their distributions impart different (desired and undesired) end product properties.  Multiple distributions often co-exist and leads to the need for a separations step in addition to characterization. Thermal field-flow fractionation (ThFFF) is demonstrated as a versatile platform for separating and characterizing complex polymers and colloids.  Ultrahigh molecular weight or ultralarge polymers and colloid surface characterizations are the foci of this project as reliable methods for determining distributions in multiple important properties do not currently exist.  

Advances achieved in the polymer analysis component of this project include 1) sample preparation techniques are compared for highly complex polysiloxane formulations where the polymer of interest is present as a minor component and the samples? molar mass (MM) span 104 Da to >107 Da and microgels are also present; 2) ThFFF is used to determine the Soret contraction factor g", marking an innovative approach to obtaining information about the degree of chain branching in the absence of standards; 3) an orthogonal method, e.g., depolymerization of polysiloxanes followed by GC-MS, was used to confirm trends in branching distribution obtained by the ThFFF-based g" approach. Both methods accurately indicated that higher crosslinked polysiloxane samples had higher degree of branching as well as higher dispersity in branching.  This first ever comparison confirms and demonstrates our progress in understanding thermal diffusion of polymers specifically for ThFFF separation and characterization; 4) different types of polymer structures appear to have different ranges of g".

Important findings in the ThFFF colloids analysis portion of this project include 1) better understanding of solution additives that impact thermal diffusion of polymer colloids. Specifically, tetrabutylammonium phosphate, strongly affects ThFFF retention whereas a surfactant containing mixture, FL-70, significantly improves sample recovery of charged polyacrylate colloids; 2) ThFFF can differentiate small differences (< 3%) in the surface composition/charge of similar size colloids as well as discern a difference in colloids that underwent thermal- and redox-initiated synthesis; 3) dynamic light scattering (DLS) measurement of diffusion coefficients D is shown to produce erroneously high values when coupled with a separation technique. This finding that the flow rate in the separation stage affects D (and thus size) is important as DLS is increasingly used as an on-line detector.

This GOALI project is a collaboration with Dow Chemical Company scientists across multiple divisions and sites. Hence, students working on this project have benefitted from guidance across a wealth of different expertise areas as they gained experience working with polymers and colloids that are relevant to industry.  The polymers and colloids provided by Dow are part of the company's progression to greener consumer products.  This academic-industry partnership brings together the expertise needed to solve important problems and transform ThFFF into a cornerstone technology that promotes economic growth and better living.  We have introduced activities related to separations, polymers, and colloids to the Rocky Mountain Camp for Dyslexic Youths as well as participate in a virtual Panhellenic Halloweve Chemistry night for elementary students. The PI (Williams) serves on the scientific program committee for the International Symposium on Field- and Flow-Based Separations (2022, 2024).  To address a wider audience, students from the P.I.'s group and two other research groups established a website (fff.separation.net) as a central point for the FFF community to exchange information.
